Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Gas Hydrate Formation and Inhibition at the Conditions Encountered in the Gulf of Mexico Oil Leak from the Deepwater Horizon Well

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1042752
Sum

The focus of this proposed project is to obtain experimental data needed in strategies currently contemplated to prevent gas hydrate formation at the oil/gas leaking from the Deepwater Horizon well system, as well as other future deepwater oil developments.

Intellectual Merit: The effect of thermodynamic inhibitors being considered, such as methanol and monoethylene glycol on hydrate formation conditions and rates in the presence of water-in-oil emulsion + brine systems will be measured using a high pressure differential calorimeter and a stirred high pressure autoclave cell. These measurements will provide new and critical information to establishing the effectiveness of these widely used control strategies for hydrate formation in deepwater oil developments. The CSM Hydrate Center is a global leader in hydrate flow assurance, with extensive expertise in experiments and modeling of hydrate formation applied to the oil industry. The proposed project will be accelerated by the expertise at CSM in hydrate experiments.

The first set of experiments will measure the phase equilibria of methane hydrates from brine solution with and without inhibitor (methanol and monoethylene glycol). These measurements will be performed in a high-pressure micro-differential scanning calorimeter (HiP-DSC). This instrument allows measurements of phase changes for very small samples (about 20 mg) at low temperature and high-pressure conditions as expected in the Deepwater Horizon well systems. For these experiments, the pressure will be set to 2500-3000 psi and the temperature ramped from +40 째C to -40 째C to form hydrates and then from -40째C to +40 째C to dissociate the hydrate and obtain the dissociation temperature of the hydrate and the extent of conversion of the aqueous brine solution to hydrate crystals. The onset of the dissociation temperature can be measured for the different samples at a number of inhibitor concentrations.

Broader Impact: The effect of thermodynamic inhibitors, such as methanol and monoethylene glycol on hydrate formation conditions and rates in the presence of water-in-oil emulsion + brine systems have not been investigated previously. Yet, this information is critical to establishing the effectiveness of these widely used control strategies for hydrate formation and remediation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RAPID: Gas Hydrate Formation and Inhibition at the Conditions Encountered in the Gulf of Mexico Oil Leak from the Deepwater Horizon Well

 

Amadeu K. Sum, Carolyn A. Koh, David T. Wu

Center for Hydrate Research, Colorado School of Mines

 

Project Summary

Intellectual Merit. The focus of this proposed project was to obtain experimental data needed in strategies to prevent gas hydrate formation at the oil/gas blowout. We report measurements of data for hydrate systems containing two thermodynamic hydrate inhibitors (salt and methanol/monoethylene glycol). Thermodynamic hydrate inhibitors (THIs) are often the easiest way to avoid hydrate plug formation. In this project we measure the effects of dually inhibited systems (sodium chloride + methanol, or sodium chloride + monoethylene glycol) from measurements in a differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) to measure equilibrium conditions and an autoclave high pressure cell to measure hydrate conversion rates for these systems. These measurements provide new and critical information to establishing the effectiveness of these widely used control strategies for hydrate formation in deepwater oil developments.

 

Broader Impact. The outcome of this project has directly impact on the remediation strategies to control gas hydrates formation in the containment of the oil leak from blowout. The data measured can be directly used to assure that the injection of methanol or ethylene glycol in seawater is effective in preventing the formation of gas hydrates at the rate and concentrations expected to be encountered in containment strategies. Moreover, gas hydrate inhibition data are unavailable in the literature, and thus there results provide a reliable data set from which all future remediation of gas hydrates could be reference.
